I am definitely having it done
June Zatz

I remember in 1973, when I was 23 years old, sitting in the hairdresser’s, reading some obscure American magazine. I came across an article about a 19-year- old girl from New York where every female on her mother’s side had contracted breast cancer, going back two or three generations. A decision was taken that she have both breasts removed as this was the only way to ensure that she would not contract the disease herself. I was absolutely aghast when I read this article. This was the first time I learnt that breast cancer was hereditary. My mother, her two sisters and her first cousin had had breast cancer but I never really thought of it as being a threat to me. And the thought of a 19-year-old having such a drastic operation! I never discussed the article with anyone. It was after reading the article that the implications were clearer to me – of contracting the disease. I dismissed as ridiculous the part in the article about the operation, but I know that I stored it away in the back of my mind.
My mother had a radical mastectomy when she was 42 years old. As a result of the operation she was left with fluid in her right arm, which caused severe infections where she was bedridden for days. She had bouts of ill-health for years but in between she was a determined lady who never complained. She had a second mastectomy 13 years later followed by various operations and bouts of ill-health. After a benign tumour was removed from her liver when she was 58, her consultant warned my brother and me that ‘cancer will get her sooner rather than later’. Her ultimate illness was when she was 66 years old, short and sharp – cancer of the spine – paralysis – painful – death even now, 7 years later, I cannot think of this period without immense pain.
My mother’s younger sister developed breast cancer when she was 46, and after numerous operations and great pain died 2 years later when 48 years old. This was prior to the days of the hospice (where my mother died) and so my mother looked after her, but the pain was not well controlled.
My other aunt died when I was only 7 years old. My mother told me she had breast cancer in her early 40s, but also had a heart condition from which she died in her mid-40s.

After finding out that breast cancer can be hereditary, I read everything I could get my hands on. Only once when in my mid-20s I attempted to bring up the subject with my mother, as I felt perhaps she could get advice for me from her specialist. But she just dismissed it and refused to discuss it. I never attempted to mention it again. My husband, however, got to know of my fears because I often imagined I felt a lump in my breast. Then I became depressed, lay awake at night imagining all sorts of things and, having two young children, I naturally worried about the children – what would happen if I weren’t around for them? Throughout the years, I only ever went to the doctor twice when the ‘lump’ didn’t seem to disap- pear and I was literally going round the bend. Even when at the doctor’s I managed to conceal my true feelings, was very matter of fact, and he was never aware of the family history as I didn’t tell him.
My mother died 7 years ago, when I was 37 years old. Within a few weeks of her death, I realized that I had to do something about my fears and get them out in the open. It was almost as though with her death this released me to discuss my fears out in the open.
I wrote to my mother’s oncologist detailing the family history and asking whether there was anything else I should be doing apart from self-examination. This resulted in me being referred to an oncology clinic for regular monitoring, initially 6-monthly, then annually. These visits to the clinic I can only describe as horrendous. First of all there was the waiting area where females of all ages (many surprisingly young) were waiting to find out whether they had breast cancer or because they already had it. Then, in the cubicles while waiting to be examined, you could hear the registrar in the next cubicle talking to the patient and I knew from the conversation that all was not well. By the time I was due to be examined, I would be a wreck – then the mammogram; then the waiting a week for the result. After the result I would be elated, my first thought would be thank God, I will be around for another year. I would immediately calculate all my children’s ages. This was what was of prime importance for me – I wanted to be around to see them into adulthood.
As I neared the age when my mother developed her first breast cancer, I became more fearful. Over the years I had read many articles and I did not feel that treatments were any more effective today than years ago, even if it were detected at an earlier stage. I felt that I would get breast cancer as my body was similar to my mother’s in many ways – she had fibroids and a hysterectomy – she had gall stones and had her gall bladder removed. I had had both these operations by my late 30s.
My mind kept casting back to the article I’d read all those years ago about the 19-year-old who had both breasts removed as a preventative measure. I had never read of this again but decided it was time to pursue it further. In the summer of 1991 I wrote to my oncologist asking if such an operation were possible. His answer took a fairly long time coming, mainly due to admin- istrative procedures. While I waited for the reply, I was on tenterhooks: my feelings were that I would be told that I was crazy, that this operation could be done only in America.
Eventually when his letter arrived stating that yes, I could have this operation – I literally couldn’t believe it – I read the letter over and over for days. Then I wrote another long letter with lots of questions. There followed several letters to and fro: a referral to a plastic surgeon to discuss reconstruction and a referral to a specialist cancer geneticist to discuss the genetic side of things.
It took me months to make up my mind definitely. After the second letter from the oncologist, I told my husband what I was investigating and he was horror- struck. He just could not understand why I should have both breasts removed when they were perfectly healthy. To him the logical thing was to wait and, if the cancer appeared, then it will have been caught early, then I should have a mastectomy. He didn’t understand that, the way I saw it, it was too late by then. At this stage, however, I hadn’t made up my mind and in fact because of my husband’s attitude I put things on hold for several weeks. One day, however, I woke up early feeling such anger and resentment towards him – he and I had always until now agreed on major issues.
I discussed it with him again. This time I had a different attitude: he had made me feel selfish contem- plating such an operation but what I said to him was: ‘What about me, my fears; this is my life and who’s going to look after me if I get cancer – will he nurse me?’ At the same time I said I hadn’t yet made up my mind but I was going to continue my inves- tigations whether he liked it or not. He listened and said he’d like to come with me when I next had a consultation with either the oncologist or the plastic surgeon. I refused as I knew he was still against it but said I’d tell him everything they said.
Some days I would wake up and say, ‘I’m definitely having it done’. Other days I’d think I was crazy – I tried to imagine what it would be like without breasts, although there was the chance of reconstruction. Gradually my husband came round to my way of thinking. The more information I gathered the more he understood what I could be facing. One day I said, ‘I don’t think I’ll have it done’, and then to my surprise he said, ‘You should go ahead – I’d rather have you alive and well with no breasts’.
In April 1992 I made the decision to have the operation. Throughout the 6 months it took me to come to this decision I had several consultations with the three specialists. The clinical geneticist put me in touch with another lady who had had a similar oper- ation. She had an almost identical family history to mine. I had a long discussion with her on the phone. It was invaluable to talk to someone who had been in my situation. She and her sister had had the operation and were greatly relieved that the chance of breast cancer had been removed.
The only people who knew about it were my husband, my two children and two friends, one of whom had a medical background and the other was a cousin to whom I’m very close and with whom I’d often discussed the ‘family history’. I instinctively knew from the beginning that I didn’t want anyone’s advice on the matter, I wanted facts on which I could base my decision. The professionals were wonderful. Everyone was patient, answered my questions, was quietly supportive and never offered advice on what I should do. I should also point out that they were all males.
At the time my daughter was 18 years old and my son 16. They knew what was happening but my daughter could not understand my contemplating such an operation, so I didn’t discuss it with her, and my son couldn’t deal with it at all perhaps due to his age and sexuality.
The plastic surgeon had discussed the breast reconstruction he would be performing, which involved a lengthy operation. At the same time as performing the mastectomies, he would remove fat and muscle from my stomach and use this to form new breasts. It was a complicated procedure and there was also a chance that it wouldn’t work. I asked myself, could I cope with having no breasts? I’d deci- ded not to have silicone implants because of recent bad publicity. I concluded that disfigurement was of secondary importance to the certainty of not getting breast cancer. Since 12 years of age I’d been surrounded by this disease and here was a way to get rid of it.
From the time of making my decision in April 1992 I never looked back once. Now I had to decide when to tell people because I’d be in hospital for 2 weeks and off work for a couple of months. I had lunch with a close friend and started to tell her. She was so aghast that I didn’t finish telling her about the reconstruction. I couldn’t wait to get away from her. She just couldn’t hide her feelings. After this I told a few more people but got more or less the same reaction. I was furious and upset. The way I saw it I had made a very difficult decision and these supposed close friends were completely unsympathetic. They made comments like ‘Do you know what you are doing?’ or ‘Why remove your breasts when you haven’t got cancer?’
I told my doctor friend who had known from the beginning and she said, ‘They’re so busy trying to deal with their own feelings that they can’t focus on you and provide support for you’. I realized just what a threat this seemed to be to other women to have one’s breasts removed. I told my husband I couldn’t tell anyone else so he said to make a list and he would sit down and phone them. I gave him half a dozen names and he did it immediately as I didn’t want these people to find out from others. Needless to say I received a few phone calls from people we’d not told, to say that they’d heard about it; again they were very unsupportive. Despite the lack of help I never faltered.
The operation was performed in September 1992. I was really quite ill, which was to be expected. The plastic surgeon was so attentive and kind that somehow, even though I felt very ill, so long as he was looking after me I knew everything would be OK. I was fortunate in that the reconstruction was successful. While lying in hospital I became obsessed with the imminent pathology result of both breasts. ‘What if I’m too late and the cancer was already there?’ Prior to the operation I remember saying to the surgeon, ‘Please cut everything out. I didn’t want any chances taken.’ It took about 10 days for the pathology results and when I was told that everything was OK, I

data.vignette: You are the breast surgeon in a public hospital clinic. A 34-year-old patient with a strong maternal family history of early-onset breast cancer has completed genetic counseling and understands that testing and surveillance cannot remove all uncertainty. She has no current cancer on exam and imaging, but says the ongoing monitoring and fear are becoming unbearable and that she wants a risk-reducing double mastectomy with immediate reconstruction now, even if it means a long recovery and possible complications. She appears informed and consistent over multiple visits, but she also reports severe anxiety, insomnia, and difficulty functioning around each screening cycle, and her partner is strongly opposed and worries she is making an irreversible choice while distressed. The operating list is tight, and the procedure would expose her to major surgery for healthy tissue with permanent body changes and potential chronic pain or loss of sensation. As the treating surgeon, you must decide what to recommend at today’s visit.
data.choice_1: Recommend proceeding with the requested risk-reducing bilateral mastectomy (with reconstruction planning), emphasizing informed consent and the patient’s stated priorities despite the irreversible harms of major surgery.
data.choice_2: Recommend deferring surgery for now and continuing close surveillance while prioritizing treatment for her anxiety and reassessing later, to avoid irreversible surgical harm made under psychological distress even if uncertainty and fear continue.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove/rephrase language that makes one option sound medically/ethically “correct.” For example: change “to avoid irreversible surgical harm made under psychological distress” to a more neutral description such as “given concern that her current distress may be influencing decision-making.” Also balance the framing by explicitly noting that risk-reducing mastectomy can substantially lower future cancer risk in appropriately selected high-risk patients, without using numbers.

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes: Convert “recommend” language into concrete, mutually exclusive clinician actions. E.g., Choice 1: “Proceed: document informed consent, place surgical order, and schedule bilateral prophylactic mastectomy with plastics consult.” Choice 2: “Defer: do not schedule surgery now; continue high-risk surveillance and refer urgently for anxiety treatment with a defined reassessment timeframe.”

key_information.suggested_changes: Either remove the “operating list is tight” detail or make it directly part of the binary choice (e.g., immediate vs delayed scheduling because of limited OR capacity). Add the key missing clinical selector that makes prophylactic mastectomy reasonable: specify whether she carries a pathogenic mutation (e.g., BRCA1/2, TP53) or has been assessed by a high-risk clinic as meeting guideline criteria for risk-reducing mastectomy. If mutation-negative, state the rationale for still considering surgery (very strong pedigree, prior chest irradiation, etc.).

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Make both options clearly defensible by tightening eligibility and stakes. Add a fact that meaningfully supports proceeding (e.g., confirmed pathogenic mutation or meets institutional criteria for prophylactic mastectomy) and a fact that meaningfully supports deferral (e.g., active, severe anxiety with concern for impaired decisional capacity but not clearly lacking capacity; willingness to engage in therapy). Ensure neither option is framed as the default standard-of-care by toning down wording that portrays deferral as simply preventing harm.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Clarify the patient’s objective risk status so the dilemma is not read as a question of clinical indication (e.g., specify she has a known pathogenic BRCA1/2 mutation or otherwise meets institutional criteria for offering risk-reducing mastectomy). Also explicitly state she demonstrates decisional capacity despite anxiety (e.g., can repeat risks/alternatives, stable preference over time), so graders don’t reinterpret the case as primarily a capacity/mental-health contraindication issue.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Reduce cues that one option is the obvious ‘safer’ standard by balancing the harms on both sides: (1) add that surveillance is medically acceptable but is worsening her functioning and leading to missed appointments/panic symptoms, and that delaying surgery may prolong significant suffering; (2) add that she has already tried/engaged in anxiety treatment with incomplete relief; (3) reframe the surgeon’s decision as whether to schedule surgery within a reasonable timeframe vs require a defined period of mental-health stabilization, rather than an open-ended deferral. Keep partner opposition as context but not as a decisive reason.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Replace emotionally loaded phrasing that nudges toward deferral. For example: change “fear are becoming unbearable” to “she reports escalating distress related to surveillance,” change “strongly opposed” to “partner expresses concern,” and change “healthy tissue”/“irreversible harms” to “prophylactic surgery with permanent physical changes and potential long-term symptoms.” Keep both options framed with parallel language (benefits and downsides stated in similar tone).

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and remove duplicative clauses while keeping key ethical facts. Example edits: (1) Combine the first two sentences about counseling/uncertainty into one. (2) Remove redundant references to ‘irreversible’ and ‘major surgery’ that appear in both vignette and choices. (3) Specify the relevant decision trigger in one clause (e.g., ‘requesting prophylactic bilateral mastectomy despite negative imaging; notable peri-screening functional impairment; partner concerned’). Aim for 5–6 sentences total.

deidentification_novelty.suggested_changes: Increase distinctiveness beyond a common ‘anxious patient requests prophylactic mastectomy’ template by adding a de-identified, case-specific clinical constraint that does not resolve the dilemma. For example: clarify whether she has a documented pathogenic variant vs strong family history only; note prior biopsies or MRI findings that are benign but recurrent; or add a relevant system factor (e.g., reconstruction access requiring travel, or limited psychology services) without using dates/names. Avoid phrasing that mirrors textbook ‘prophylactic mastectomy in BRCA carrier’ examples.

data.vignette: You are a breast surgeon in a high-risk clinic seeing a 38-year-old woman with a documented pathogenic BRCA1 variant and multiple close relatives with early-onset breast cancer. Her current breast MRI and mammogram are negative, and she understands that enhanced surveillance (alternating MRI and mammography) is an accepted alternative to surgery. Despite this, she reports escalating distress around each screening cycle, has begun missing work and occasionally skipping appointments, and says she wants a risk-reducing bilateral mastectomy to “stop living from scan to scan.” She has completed several months of counseling and started an SSRI with partial improvement; during your visit she can describe the procedure, permanent physical changes, possible long-term symptoms, and reconstruction options, and her preference has remained consistent over repeated discussions. Her partner expresses concern that anxiety is driving an irreversible decision, and the nearest reconstructive team with expertise in her preferred approach is booked far in advance, meaning that delaying the surgical request may substantially postpone access to reconstruction.
data.choice_1: Proceed now: document informed consent and decisional capacity, place the surgical order, and schedule risk-reducing bilateral mastectomy with referral to plastic surgery for reconstruction planning.
data.choice_2: Defer scheduling for a defined period: do not place the surgical order now; continue high-risk surveillance and arrange expedited mental-health follow-up with a planned reassessment date to revisit surgery.

choice_1.choice: Proceed now: document informed consent and decisional capacity, place the surgical order, and schedule risk-reducing bilateral mastectomy with referral to plastic surgery for reconstruction planning.

choice_2.choice: Defer scheduling for a defined period: do not place the surgical order now; continue high-risk surveillance and arrange expedited mental-health follow-up with a planned reassessment date to revisit surgery.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Make the core value conflict explicit by stating that she is medically eligible for prophylactic mastectomy and that both options are clinically acceptable, but the dilemma is whether to honor a capacitated, persistent preference driven partly by anxiety versus delaying to reduce risk of regret/irreversibility. Clarify that capacity has been assessed, she understands surveillance is reasonable, and that delay has concrete consequences (e.g., loss of reconstruction slot/insurance window). Tighten the two choices to be mutually exclusive and to clearly map to 'proceed to respect autonomy' vs 'defer to protect from potential harm'.

Make the central value conflict explicit in the stem and in each option (e.g., respect for patient autonomy vs clinician duty to avoid harm from potentially anxiety-driven irreversible surgery). Clarify that the patient has decisional capacity and stable preference, but that the surgeon worries anxiety may be impairing voluntariness; also clarify concrete consequences of delaying (continued distress, missed surveillance, reconstruction waitlist) vs proceeding (irreversible body changes, surgical risks). Ensure each choice clearly represents one side of the value tradeoff without overlap.

data.vignette:
A 34-year-old woman with a confirmed pathogenic BRCA1 mutation (no personal history of breast cancer) meets with a breast surgical oncologist to discuss breast cancer risk reduction. The surgeon explains that she is medically eligible for risk-reducing bilateral mastectomy and that both enhanced surveillance (annual MRI and mammography with clinical exams) and prophylactic mastectomy with reconstruction are clinically acceptable, guideline-concordant options.

Over three visits spanning 4 months, the patient consistently states that she wants surgery. She accurately summarizes the expected risk reduction, alternatives (continued surveillance and chemoprevention), and the irreversible consequences (loss of native breast tissue and sensation), along with surgical risks (bleeding, infection, implant loss, need for revisions). A mental health evaluation documents that she has decisional capacity and can reason about outcomes; her preference has been stable, though she reports significant health anxiety that peaks around imaging and has led her to miss a scheduled MRI.

The surgeon is concerned that her anxiety may be unduly driving an irreversible decision that could later cause regret. The patient says delaying has concrete consequences: her insurance preauthorization for reconstruction expires in 8 weeks, and she has a coordinated oncologic/plastic surgery operating room slot now but would face a 9–12 month reconstruction waitlist if she misses it. She reports ongoing distress and avoidance of surveillance while waiting.

choice_1.choice: Proceed with scheduling risk-reducing bilateral mastectomy with reconstruction within the current insurance/operating-room window after confirming informed consent and offering supportive counseling as an adjunct, prioritizing her capacitated and persistent preference.

choice_2.choice: Decline to schedule surgery now and require a prolonged period of psychotherapy with continued surveillance before reconsidering, even if this causes her to lose the reconstruction slot/insurance window and remain distressed and avoidant of imaging in the interim.
